title: The 5 Distances / 7 Punches
subtitle: Understand the 5 distances — know when and where to strike and what to strike with.

steps.text: Distance in boxing depends on factors like your and your opponent’s reach. The diagram shows your position (solid prints) and your opponent’s (clear prints).
1 - Out of range: neither you nor your opponent can land a punch. This is the safe zone.
2 - Edge of range: a single step allows you both to land a jab.
3 - Long range: straight shots are possible but hooks and uppercuts are not fully effective.
4 - Mid range: all punches — jabs, crosses, hooks, uppercuts — can land.
5 - Short range: hooks and uppercuts dominate. Straight punches become less effective.
Punch numbers most gyms use: 1 - Lead Jab, 2 - Rear Cross, 3 - Lead Hook, 4 - Rear Uppercut, 5 - Lead Uppercut, 6 - Rear Hook Body, 7 - Lead Hook Body.

takeaways: Distance determines shot selection — different ranges favor different punches.
There are 5 key range zones: Out of range, Edge, Long, Mid, and Short.
Basic punch numbers (1–7) help you learn combinations and drills.

title: Straight Shots
subtitle: Straight Shots: Precision and Power Through Perfect Form

steps.text: Lead jab to the head – In stance, rotate your hips towards your rear side. Extend your lead arm, turning your fist over just before impact and clenching. Keep your elbow from flaring. Rear hand stays near your chin.
Front view of lead jab to the head – Keep elbow tucked, rear hand near chin, chin down, eyes ahead. Lift lead heel slightly to release hip. Return to stance after punch.
Lead jab to the body – Rotate toward your rear foot and bend over slightly. Place weight over rear foot. Extend lead arm, fist clenched and turned over at impact.
Front view of jab to the body – Aim just below opponent's chest. Lift lead heel to help turn the hip. Return to stance after punch.
Rear cross to the head – Rotate hips to your lead side while extending rear arm. Twist rear foot like grinding a cigarette. Rear foot toes should face opponent. Clench fist on impact.
Front view of rear cross – Hips parallel to opponent, rear foot twisted forward, chin tucked, eyes ahead. Return to stance after punch.
Rear cross to the body – Start by squatting down about head-height. Bend knees, keep rear heel off ground.
From the crouched position, rotate hips and rear foot to face opponent. Extend rear arm and clench fist at impact. Don’t lean forward — power comes from the hips.
Front view of rear cross to body – Chin tucked, eyes forward, lead hand guarding chin, rear fist turned over at impact. Return to stance after punch.

takeaways: Every straight punch starts with hip rotation and ends with a clenched fist and a quick return to stance.
Keep elbows tucked, chin down, and eyes forward to stay protected.
Rear foot pivot and lead heel lift are crucial for power and proper hip engagement.

title: Hooks
subtitle: Hooks: Mastering Short, Powerful Shots to the Head and Body

steps.text: Lead hook head – In your stance, start by turning your hips toward your rear side while leaving your lead arm out in position.
Whip your lead hook with thumb up, palm facing your body. Lead heel may lift slightly to help rotate hip. Chin tucked, eyes forward, rear hand shields chin.
Lead hook body – Hinge at the hips to shift your upper body weight over the lead leg. Don’t lean forward.
Drop your lead arm to set up the punch. Weight remains over your lead leg, balanced and ready.
Turn your hips toward your rear side. Punch with palm up, clenching fist on impact. Return to stance.
Rear hook head – Start by twisting your hips toward your lead side and rotating your rear foot. Leave rear arm in place.
Whip your rear hook through with thumb up. Lead hand guards chin, chin down, eyes forward.
Rear hook body – Hinge at the waist to place your weight over the rear leg. Don’t lean back.
Let your rear arm drop naturally to prepare for the punch.
Pivot on your rear toe, shift your weight forward, and punch with palm up. Lead hand protects chin. Return to stance.

takeaways: Hooks combine hip rotation and arm whip, with thumb up and fist clenched at impact.
Keep your chin down, eyes forward, and your opposite hand guarding your face.
Proper weight shift and pivot generate power without losing balance—always reset to stance.

title: Uppercuts
subtitle: Uppercuts: Power From Below to Break Through the Guard

steps.text: Lead uppercut head – Hinge at the hip and place your weight over your lead foot.
Drop your lead hand. Keep opposite hand high to protect your chin. Eyes forward, chin tucked.
Turn hips toward your rear side and drive your lead fist upward. Clench on impact. Keep chin down, eyes forward.
Rear uppercut head – Hinge at the hip and shift weight over the rear foot.
Drop your rear hand to prepare for the punch.
Twist your hips on the ball of the rear foot while punching upward with your rear hand. Lead hand protects chin, eyes forward, chin tucked.

takeaways: Uppercuts start with hip hinge and weight shift to load power properly.
Power comes from the hips — rotate and drive upward, clenching on impact.
Always keep your opposite hand protecting your chin, eyes forward, chin tucked.
